questions.question_text: In Amazon RDS for PostgreSQL, you can provision up to 3TB storage and 30,000 IOPS per database instance. For a workload with 50% writes and 50% reads running on a cr1.8xlarge instance, you can realize over 25,000 IOPS for PostgreSQL. However, by provisioning more than this limit, you may be able to achieve:
questions.answer_description:
You can provision up to 3TB storage and 30,000 IOPS per database instance. For a workload with 50% writes and 50% reads running on a cr1.8xlarge instance, you can realize over 25,000 IOPS for PostgreSQL. However, by provisioning more than this limit, you may be able to achieve lower latency and higher throughput.
Your actual realized IOPS may vary from the amount you provisioned based on your database workload, instance type, and database engine choice.
Reference:
https://aws.amazon.com/rds/postgresql/

discussion.content: C. higher throughput only.

You can provision up to 3TB storage and 30,000 IOPS per database instance. For a workload with 50% writes and 50% reads running on a cr1.8xlarge instance, you can realize over 25,000 IOPS for PostgreSQL. However, by provisioning more than this limit, you may be able to achieve lower latency and higher throughput. Your actual realized IOPS may vary from the amount you provisioned based on your database workload, instance type, and database engine choice.

questions.answer_description:
AWS Data Pipeline is a web service that helps you reliably process and move data between different AWS compute and storage services as well as on premise data sources at specified intervals. With AWS Data Pipeline, you can regularly access your data where it's stored, transform and process it at scale, and efficiently transfer the results to another AWS.
AWS Data Pipeline helps you easily create complex data processing workloads that are fault tolerant, repeatable, and highly available. AWS Data Pipeline also allows you to move and process data that was previously locked up in on premise data silos.
Reference:
http://aws.amazon.com/datapipeline/
questions.question_text: Which of the following cannot be done using AWS Data Pipeline?

discussion.content: C. Generate reports over data that has been stored.

Selected Answer: C
Option C, "Generate reports over data that has been stored," cannot be done directly using AWS Data Pipeline.

AWS Data Pipeline is a web service that allows you to orchestrate and automate the movement and processing of data between different AWS services and on-premises data sources. It is designed for managing and orchestrating complex data processing workloads. However, generating reports over stored data typically involves querying and analyzing the data, which is not a direct functionality provided by AWS Data Pipeline.

To generate reports over stored data in AWS, you can use other services such as Amazon Athena, Amazon Redshift, or Amazon QuickSight. These services provide querying, analysis, and visualization capabilities that can be used to generate reports based on the stored data.

C.
keyword here is 'reports'

Looks like C is correct. There is no documentation about creating report.

choices.C: Generate reports over data that has been stored.
choices.A: Create complex data processing workloads that are fault tolerant, repeatable, and highly available.

choices.B: You can choose the name of the AWS Direct Connection as the resource.

discussion.content:
Answer is C
But now DirectConnect has provide ARNs
https://docs.aws.amazon.com/directconnect/latest/UserGuide/security_iam_service-with-iam.html
C. You can use an asterisk (*) as the resource.

AWS Direct Connect itself has no specific resources for you to control access to. Therefore, there are no AWS Direct Connect ARNs for you to use in an IAM policy. You use an asterisk (*) as the resource when writing a policy to control access to AWS Direct Connect actions.

Question is bit old. Now it's possible to use direct connect arn as stated here : 

https://docs.aws.amazon.com/directconnect/latest/UserGuide/security_iam_service-with-iam.html

This fine grained control. If this doesn't fulfill the requirement then star(*) can be used. For the sake of the question, C is correct choice here.

questions.answer_description:
AWS Direct Connect itself has no specific resources for you to control access to. Therefore, there are no AWS Direct Connect ARNs for you to use in an IAM policy. You use an asterisk (*) as the resource when writing a policy to control access to AWS Direct Connect actions.
Reference:
http://docs.aws.amazon.com/directconnect/latest/UserGuide/using_iam.html
questions.question_text:
AWS Direct Connect itself has NO specific resources for you to control access to. Therefore, there are no AWS Direct Connect Amazon Resource Names (ARNs) for you to use in an Identity and Access Management (IAM) policy.
With that in mind, how is it possible to write a policy to control access to AWS Direct Connect actions?

questions.answer_description:
A task runner is an application that polls AWS Data Pipeline for tasks and then performs those tasks. You can either use Task Runner as provided by AWS Data
Pipeline, or create a custom Task Runner application.
Task Runner is a default implementation of a task runner that is provided by AWS Data Pipeline. When Task Runner is installed and configured, it polls AWS Data
Pipeline for tasks associated with pipelines that you have activated. When a task is assigned to Task Runner, it performs that task and reports its status back to
AWS Data Pipeline. If your workflow requires non-default behavior, you'll need to implement that functionality in a custom task runner.
Reference:
http://docs.aws.amazon.com/datapipeline/latest/DeveloperGuide/dp-how-remote-taskrunner-client.html
questions.question_text: Identify an application that polls AWS Data Pipeline for tasks and then performs those tasks.

discussion.content: C. A task runner

Selected Answer: C
Sure C

A task runner is an application that polls AWS Data Pipeline for tasks and then performs those tasks.

questions.question_text: How is AWS readily distinguished from other vendors in the traditional IT computing landscape?

choices.C: Secure. Flexible. Cost-effective. Scalable and elastic. Experienced
choices.A: Experienced. Scalable and elastic. Secure. Cost-effective. Reliable
choices.B: Secure. Flexible. Cost-effective. Scalable and elastic. Global
